content.webTitle: England recall Chris Ashton to add poaching power against New Zealand | Robert Kitson

fields.headline: England recall Chris Ashton to add poaching power against New Zealand
fields.bodyText: Summer holidays are less enjoyable if a few sharp rocks are wedged under your beach towel. So said Steve Hansen, the All Blacks head coach, after his side’s loss to England at Twickenham 18 months ago, a defeat he predicted would niggle him for months. It will be much the same for Stuart Lancaster should New Zealand complete a 3-0 series “blackwash”. Another home win would also ensure a fourth straight defeat to the All Blacks this season, with a further psychologically-important meeting to come in London in November. As the England wing Chris Ashton succinctly put it on the eve of the third Test: “We’d all be pretty upset to lose 3-0.” Lancaster’s touring team desperately want to fly home having reinforced their competitive credentials 15 months out from the 2015 Rugby World Cup. Watching England’s footballers in Brazil has only served to highlight the areas Lancaster and his coaches still have to address. Had Luis Suárez been playing for England they would surely have won, so irresistibly sharp were the Uruguayan’s finishing instincts. A shortage of world-class anticipation and a reliable cutting edge have also been among English rugby’s recurring issues; they will not lift their own World Cup either until such qualities have been instilled. Andy Farrell, England’s assistant coach, conceded as much after England’s final training session of the tour. Hailing New Zealand as “the best side in the world at getting over the line” in tight games, he is demanding greater attacking accuracy from his own players. “The All Blacks are composed when it really matters and we can learn a big lesson from that. It’s about recognising the opportunity, not over-playing, being one step ahead and striking while the iron’s hot.” Quite so. It makes the return of the try-poaching Ashton on England’s wing doubly intriguing. Until the last three months, self-doubt had begun to cloak his talent. Would he have run in the long-range try that Manu Tuilagi could not score in Dunedin? Recent evidence strongly suggests so. But can he become as prolific a figure at the highest level as Julian Savea? The latter is currently the standard by which all English wings need to be measured. Ashton has already scored one try in this series despite having only been on the field for a few minutes and believes the dark days of midwinter, when he lost his Test place, are behind him. “I’ve just enjoyed it again: You sometimes forget that but it’s the main reason why I’m here. “Confidence is a funny thing sometimes. When things aren’t going your way it is hard.” Lancaster, in turn, has been suitably reassured by the efforts the 27-year-old has made to improve his defence and produce the calmer decisions Farrell is seeking. The head coach also reminded the Saracens wing it was “better to be the hunter than the hunted”, precisely the kind of reassuring yet proactive message Ashton needed to hear. It has also helped ensure that, unlike his fellow Wiganer Joel Tomkins, Ashton is happy to stay in union and take his chances. He prefers to trust his on-field instincts, too, reckoning he plays best when he avoids overthinking. That may just be true as well of England’s other league import, Kyle Eastmond. Not for the first time English rugby has turned to the 13-man code for something different and Ashton reckons union supporters have yet to fully appreciate the Bath centre. “He has an unbelievable skill set that has yet to be shown in union,” suggested Ashton. “The more experience he gets he’ll be one hell of a threat.” Ashton also reckons the Bath-bound Sam Burgess will have a thunderbolt’s impact when he arrives from South Sydney, regardless of what union purists think: “He won’t take much bedding-in time ... his size and the threat he poses make him a completely different kettle of fish.” But power and speed are all very well; England need to think more clearly to outwit an All Blacks side who have not been ahead at half-time in four of their last five games and still won the lot. As England’s captain, Chris Robshaw, has reiterated to his players, rocket science is not involved. “A lot of times it’s just doing the basics well,” he said. “In the 50th minute when the ball has been in play for a couple of minutes ... who still has that mental capacity to do the right thing at the right time? That’s what it comes down to.” England, adds Robshaw, also feel they have “nothing to lose” this weekend. Geoff Parling’s late withdrawal with a hamstring strain may encourage the All Black lineout but the visiting pack, with Joe Launchbury now starting and Dave Attwood on the bench, insist they still have one final push left in them. “A lot of us probably won’t get the opportunity to come to New Zealand again as a touring party so it is kind of now or never,” suggested Robshaw. “That’s the mentality we are taking into this game. We can still finish the season on a high.” Either way, insists Farrell, England’s rivals will be “a little bit nervous” by the time the World Cup comes around. “We’ll be on fire by the World Cup, there’ll be no doubt about that.” The increasing respect England have gained around New Zealand for their courtesy and behaviour on this tour will, even so, be of only limited consolation should they lose again now. “They might say nice things about us but deep down they’d love a 3-0,” suggested Ashton. “Because we’ve pushed them so close we’d like to get a win. They’ll know it’s not been done by England here since 2003 which turned out to be an unbelievable year for that team. I don’t see why we can’t do the same.” If the All Blacks win again, on the other hand, there will be a lot of rocks beneath English beach towels this summer. This is a big game for ... Ben Youngs Scrum-half has been a problematic area for England on this trip. Danny Care’s unfortunate training ground tumble effectively ruled him out of two Tests and he did not look himself in Dunedin either. Youngs was equally fallible in Auckland and can ill afford another poor performance now. Freddie Burns Burns does not suffer massively from nerves, which is just as well. If he can replicate the assurance he showed at Eden Park, he will join Leicester this summer with his confidence fully restored. Take a step backwards and Danny Cipriani is coming up fast on the rails. Owen Farrell’s knee injury has made this another massive opportunity for both men. Kyle Eastmond In, out, shake it all about. The English midfield hokey-cokey continues, with Eastmond and Manu Tuilagi reunited in the centres and both Billy Twelvetrees and Luther Burrell jettisoned. If Eastmond, in particular, causes more problems on the gainline, Stuart Lancaster will find it hard to drop him this autumn. Chris Ashton With the Tuilagi wing project failing to take flight in Dunedin, this is Ashton’s chance to show what he can do. He already has 19 Test tries in 38 Tests for England but lost his place in the Six Nations. Jack Nowell, Jonny May, Christian Wade and Anthony Watson will all be looking on with interest. Dylan Hartley Hartley has been waiting for this opportunity for years: a Test match up the road from his native Rotorua, a chance to show Kiwis what they missed when he left for England as a teenager. With Rob Webber having enhanced his reputation on this trip and Tom Youngs still part of the hooking equation, it is a big game for Hartley all round. New Zealand team for the third Test B Smith (Highlanders); Jane (Hurricanes), Fekitoa (Highlanders), Nonu (Blues), Savea (Hurricanes); Cruden (Chiefs), A Smith (Highlanders); Woodcock (Blues), Coles (Hurricanes), Franks (Crusaders), Retallick (Chiefs), Whitelock (Crusaders), Kaino (Blues), McCaw (Crusaders, capt), Read (Crusaders). Replacements Mealamu (Blues), Crockett (Crusaders), Faumuina (Blues), Tuipulotu (Blues), Messam (Chiefs), Perenara (Hurricanes), Barrett (Hurricanes), Crotty (Crusaders). England team for the third Test Brown (Harlequins); Ashton (Saracens), Tuilagi (Leicester), Eastmond (Bath), Yarde (Harlequins); Burns (Leicester), Youngs (Leicester); Marler (Harlequins), Hartley (Northampton), Wilson (Bath), Lawes (Northampton), Launchbury (London Wasps), Wood (Northampton), Robshaw (Harlequins, capt), B Vunipola (Saracens), Replacements Webber (Bath), Mullan (London Wasps), Brookes (Newcastle), Attwood (Bath), Morgan (Gloucester), L Dickson (Northampton), Cipriani (Sale), Burrell (Northampton). Referee J Garces (France).
